apidoc:function.name: server-default-xquery-version
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Return the default xquery version of the App Server, XDBC Server, ODBC Server, or Task Server with the given ID. For a Task Server, return the empty sequence.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An App Server, XDBC Server, ODBC Server, or Task Server ID.

apidoc:function.name: forest-name
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Return the name of the forest with the given ID.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A forest ID.

apidoc:function.name: forest-host
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Return the host of the forest with the given id.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A forest ID.

apidoc:function.name: forest-failover-info
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Return a sequence of pair of the forest IDs and host IDs for the failover forests and hosts of the given forest.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A forest ID.

apidoc:function.name: databases
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns a sequence of the IDs of all the databases in the system.

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp.databases(); => A Sequence with the IDs of the databases, for example: 14389140626518478220 8456374036761185098 10615125154705099114

apidoc:function.name: forests
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns a sequence of the IDs of all the forests in the system.

apidoc:function.name: forest-databases
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the database ID corresponding to the database to which the specified forest belongs, or empty sequence if the forest belongs to no database.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A forest ID.

apidoc:function.name: document-get
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the document in the file specified by $location.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The location of the input document. If the scheme of the location is HTTP (that is, if the string starts with "http://"), then the document is requested over HTTP. If the scheme is file (that is, if the string starts with "file://"), then the document is requested over file protocol from the local filesystem. Otherwise, the document is fetched from the local filesystem. On the filesystem, the path can be fully qualifed or relative. Relative pathnames are resolved from the directory in which MarkLogic Server is installed.

Options with which to customize this operation. You can specify options as either an XML element in the "xdmp:document-get" namespace, or as a map:map. The options names below are XML element localnames. When using a map, replace the hyphens with camel casing. For example, "an-option" becomes "anOption" when used as a map:map key. This function supports the following options, as well as options from xdmp:httpGet xdmp.httpGet when retrieving content via an HTTP request. Options from xdmp:http-get must be in the xdmp:http namespace.
<default-namespace>
defaultNamespace The namespace to use if there is no namespace at the root node of the document. The default value is "".
<repair>
repair A value of full specifies that malformed XML content be repaired. A value of none specifies that malformed XML content is rejected.
If no repair option is explicitly specified, the default is implicitly specified by the XQuery version of the caller. In XQuery 1.0 and 1.0-ml the default is none. In XQuery 0.9-ml the default is full.
If no repair option is explicitly specified, the default is none. This option has no effect on binary, text or JSON documents.
<format>
format A value of text specifies to get the document as a text document, regardless of the URI specified. A value of binary specifies to get the document as a binary document, regardless of the URI specified. A value of xml specifies to get the document as an XML document, regardless of the URI specified. A value of json specifies to get the document as a JSON document, regardless of the URI specified.
<default-language>
defaultLanguage The language to specify in an xml:lang attribute on the root element node if the root element node does not already have an xml:lang attribute. This option applies only to XML documents. If this option is not specified, then nothing is added to the root element node.
<encoding>
encoding Specifies the encoding to use when reading the document into MarkLogic Server. The value must either be "auto" or match an encoding name according to the Unicode Charset Alias Matching rules (http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr22/#Charset_Alias_Matching). When the value is "auto", MarkLogic guesses the encoding from the document content. For a list of character set encodings by language, see Collations and Character Sets By Language in the Search Developer's Guide. If you do not set this option, MarkLogic uses the encoding specified in the HTTP headers, if present. If you do not set this option and no encoding is available from HTTP headers, the encoding defaults to UTF-8. For more details, see Character Encoding in the Search Developer's Guide.

apidoc:usage.p: If no format is specified in $options, and the document is from an HTTP server, the format is specified by the document content type from the HTTP response. If no format is specified in $options, and the document is from the filesystem, the format is specified by the document content type from the filename extension. The mimetype extensions and corresponding content types are set in the Admin Interface.

When the document is from an HTTP server, xdmp:document-get xdmp.documentGet will always return the response from the HTTP server, even if it is an error response such as 404 or 500. If you want to be able to examine the response header in your application, use the xdmp:http-get xdmp.httpGet instead, which returns both the response header and the response.

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp:document-get("myDocument.xml") => the xml contained in myDocument.xml, for example, <myDocument/>
xdmp:document-get("myDocument.html", <options xmlns="xdmp:document-get"> <repair>full</repair> </options>) => myDocument.html as an XML document that has gone through any needed tag repair

xdmp:document-get("http://myCompany.com/file.xml", <options xmlns="xdmp:document-get" xmlns:http="xdmp:http"> <format>xml</format> <http:authentication> <http:username>user</http:username> <http:password>pass</http:password> </http:authentication> </options>) => gets an XML document named file.xml, sending the authentication credentials user/pass to the http://myCompany.com server

apidoc:function.name: get
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary:
[DEPRECATED: use xdmp:document-get instead] Returns the document in the XML file specified by $path.
This function is deprecated and will be removed from a future release. Use xdmp:document-get instead.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The path to the input file. The path can be fully qualifed or relative. Relative pathnames are resolved from the directory in which MarkLogic Server is installed.

Default namespace for nodes in the first parameter. If $default-namespace is specified and the root node of the loaded document does not explicitly specify a namespace, $default-namespace will be applied to the root node. The default value for $default-namespace is "".

The options for getting this document. The default value is ().
Options include:
"repair-full" Specifies that malformed XML content be repaired. This option has no effect on binary or text documents. "repair-none" Specifies that malformed XML content be rejected. This option has no effect on binary or text documents. "format-text" Specifies to get the document as a text document, regardless of the URI specified. "format-binary" Specifies to get the document as a binary document, regardless of the URI specified. "format-xml" Specifies to get the document as an XML document, regardless of the URI specified. "format-json" Specifies to get the document as a JSON document, regardless of the URI specified. "lang=en" Specifies that the document is in english.

apidoc:usage.p: If no format is specified in $options, it is specified by the document content type specified by the extension of the document URI. The mimetype extensions and corresponding content types are set in the Admin Interface.

If neither "repair-full" nor "repair-none" is present, the default is specified by the XQuery version of the caller. In XQuery version 1.0 and 1.0-ml the default is "repair-none". In XQuery version 0.9-ml the default is "repair-full".

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp:get("foo.html", "", ("repair-full", "format-xml")) => foo.html as an XML document that has gone through any needed tag repair

apidoc:function.name: directory
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the documents from the database in a directory. Note that these are database documents, not from the filesystem; if you want documents from a filesystem directory, use xdmp:filesystem-directoryxdmp.filesystemDirectory instead.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The URI of the directory. Typically, directory URIs end with a forward slash (/).
"1" for immediate children, "infinity" for all. If not supplied, depth is "1".

apidoc:function.name: directory-properties
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns a sequence of properties documents, one for each document in the specified directory that has a corresponding properties document.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The URI of the directory. Typically, directory URIs end with a forward slash (/).
"1" for immediate children, "infinity" for all children. If not supplied, depth is "1".

apidoc:example.pre:
xdmp:directory-properties("http://example.com/dir/","1") => <prop:properties xmlns:prop="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/property"> <prop:directory/> </prop:properties>
The properties document returned has one directory element, indicating that there is a single directory that is an immediate child of the specified directory.

xdmp.directoryProperties("http://example.com/dir/","1"); => <prop:properties xmlns:prop="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/property"> <prop:directory/> </prop:properties>
The properties document returned has one directory element, indicating that there is a single directory that is an immediate child of the specified directory.

apidoc:function.name: collection-properties
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns a sequence of properties documents, one for each document in the specified collection(s) that has a corresponding properties document.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The URI(s) of the collection(s).

apidoc:function.name: directory-locks
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns locks of documents in a directory.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The URI of the directory. Typically, directory URIs end with a forward slash (/).
"1" for immediate children, "infinity" for all. If not supplied, depth is "1".

apidoc:function.name: collection-locks
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns locks of documents in a collection.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The input URI.

apidoc:function.name: uri-content-type
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the content type of the given URI as matched in the mimetypes configuration. xdmp:content-type continues to work too.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The document URI.

apidoc:function.name: uri-format
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the format of the given URI as matched in the mimetypes configuration.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The document URI.

apidoc:function.name: document-get-properties
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the property values for a document's property. Throws XDMP-DOCNOTFOUND if there is no document at the specifed URI.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The document URI.
The property name. This is the QName of the top-level property element in the specified properties document.

apidoc:function.name: access
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns whether a given action on the specified document URI would succeed.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The document URI.
The type of access: "create", "insert", "update", "node-update" or "execute".

apidoc:function.name: http-get
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Sends the http GET method to the specified URI. Returns the http response as well as whatever information is identified by the specified URI (for example, an html document).

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The URI of the requested document.

Options with which to customize this operation. You can specify options as either an XML element in the "xdmp:http" namespace, or as a map:map. The options names below are XML element localnames. When using a map, replace the hyphens with camel casing. For example, "an-option" becomes "anOption" when used as a map:map key. This function supports the following options, plus certain options from the xdmp:document-load xdmp.documentLoad and xdmp:document-get xdmp.documentGet functions. For example, you can use the repair and encoding options from these functions. When including an option from another function in an XML options node, use the namespace appropriate to that function in the option element.
<headers>
headers A sequence of <name>value</name> pairs. The names can be anything, but many HTTP servers understand HTTP names such as content-type. These are turned into name:value HTTP headers. An error is raised if the child elements of the <headers> option are not of the form <name>value</name>. An object with each of its properties representing one HTTP header. The name of the property is the header's name and the value of the property is the header's value. The names can be anything, but many HTTP servers understand HTTP names such as content-type.
<credential-id>
credentialId The credential id to use for authentication. This is the preferred way of providing authentication credentials because they are stored securely in the security database. When a credential id is specified, the other authentication information fields should be left empty and will be ignored. For details on obtaining a credential id, see the Usage Notes, below.
<authentication>
authentication The credentials and the authentication method to use for this request. This element can contain the following child elements:
username: The username of the user to be authenticated on the http server
password: The password for username.
The authentication element can also include an optional method attribute with one of the following values: basic, digest, aws, aws4, negotiate. If the authentication method is specified and the HTTP server requests a different type of authentication, then an error is raised. The credentials and the authentication method to use for this request. This property can contain the following child properties:
username: The username of the user to be authenticated on the http server
password: The password for username.
method: Optional. The authentication method. Allowed values: basic, digest, aws, aws4. If a method is specified and the HTTP server requests a different type of authentication, then an error is raised.
<timeout>
timeout The amount of time, in seconds, to wait until the HTTP connection times out. The default value is the http timeout for the group.
<ciphers>
ciphers A standard cipher string. For details on legal ciper strings, see http://www.openssl.org/docs/apps/ciphers.html#CIPHER_STRINGS.
<client-cert>
client-cert A PEM encoded client certificate for identifying the client to the remote server.
<client-key>
clientKey The private key that corresponds to client-certclientCert.
<pass-phrase>
passPhrase A pass phrase, if one is needed to decrypt client-key.
<allow-sslv3>
allowSslv3 A boolean value to specify whether to communicate using the SSL v3 protocol. The default is true, which indicates communication using the SSL v3 protocol.
<allow-tls>
allowTls A boolean value to specify whether to communicate using the TLS protocol. The default is true, which indicates communication using the TLS protocol.
<verify-cert>
verifyCert A boolean value to specify whether the server's certificate should be verified. The default value is true. A value of false should only be specfied after careful consideration of the security risks since it permits communication with servers whose certificates are expired, revoked, or signed by unknown or untrusted authorities. A value of false also removes protection against a man-in-the-middle attack.
<ssl-session-cache>
sslSessionCache A boolean value to specify whether ssl session should be cached and reused. The default value is true. A value of false should only be specfied if ssl session cache causes problem with a url.

apidoc:usage.p: The http functions only operate on URIs that use the http or https schemes; specifying a URI that does not begin with http:// or https:// throws an exception.
If an http function times out, it throws a socket received exception (SVC-SOCRECV).

An automatic encoding detector will be used if the value auto is specified for the encoding option (in the xdmp:document-get namespace). If no option is specified, the encoding defaults to the encoding specified in the http header. If there is no encoding in the http header, the encoding defaults to UTF-8.
The first node in the output of this function is the response header from the http server.

The second node in the output of this function is the response from the http server. The response is treated as text, XML, JSON or binary, depending on the content-type header sent from the http server. If the node is html, the header should indicate text/html, which is returned as a text document by default. The type of document is determined by the mimetypes mappings, and you can change the mappings in the Admin Interface as needed.
If you happen to know that the response is XML, even if the header does not specify it as XML, and want to process the response as XML, you can wrap the response in an xdmp:unquote call to parse the response as XML. You could also use the <format>xml</format> option (in the xdmp:document-get namespace) to tell the API to treat the document as XML. Also, if you know the response is an HTML document, you can wrap the response in an xdmp:tidy call, which will treat the text as HTML, clean it up, and return an XHTML XML document.

Note that for "options", you can pass it in also as a map:map. Each map entry represents one option and the naming convention of the options is the same as the one used when calling the function from JavaScript.

If you use the credential-id option, you can use xdmp:credential-id to obtain the id of a previously stored credential. For example:
xdmp:http-get($someuri <options xmlns="xdmp:http"> <credential-id>{xdmp:credential-id("my-credential-name)}</credential-id> </options>)

If you use the credentialId option, you can use xdmp.credentialId to obtain the id of a previously stored credential. For example:
xdmp.httpGet( someuri, { credentialId: xdmp.credentialId('myCredentialName') })

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp:http-get("http://www.my.com/document.xhtml", <options xmlns="xdmp:http"> <authentication method="basic"> <username>myname</username> <password>mypassword</password> </authentication> </options>) => the response from the server as well as the specified document

xdmp:http-get("http://www.my.com/iso8859document.html", <options xmlns="xdmp:document-get"> <encoding>iso-8859-1</encoding> </options>)[2] => The specified document, transcoded from ISO-8859-1 to UTF-8 encoding. This assumes the document is encoded in ISO-8859-1. Note that the encoding option is in the "xdmp:document-get" namespace.

xdmp:unquote( xdmp:http-get("http://www.my.com/somexml.xml")[2]) => The specified xml document, parsed as XML by xdmp:unquote. If the header specifies a mimetype that is configured to be treated as XML, the xdmp:unquote call is not needed. Alternately, you can treat the response as XML by specifying XML in the options node as follows (note that the format option is in the "xdmp:document-get" namespace:
xdmp:http-get("http://www.my.com/somexml.xml", <options xmlns="xdmp:http-get"> <format xmlns="xdmp:document-get">xml</format> </options>)[2]

apidoc:function.name: http-head
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Sends the http HEAD method to the specified URI. Returns the http response header for the specified URI.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The URI of the document whose response header is being requested.

Options with which to customize this operation. You can specify options as either an XML element in the "xdmp:http" namespace, or as a map:map. For details on the supported options, see xdmp:http-getxdmp.httpGet.

apidoc:usage.p: The http functions only operate on URIs that use the http or https schemes; specifying a URI that does not begin with http:// or https:// throws an exception.
If an http function times out, it throws a socket received exception (SVC-SOCRECV).

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp:http-head("http://www.my.com/document.xhtml", <options xmlns="xdmp:http"> <authentication method="basic"> <username>myname</username> <password>mypassword</password> </authentication> </options>) => the response header from the server

apidoc:function.name: http-options
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Sends the http OPTIONS method to the specified URI. Returns the http response for the specified URI.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The URI of the document whose options response is being requested.

Options with which to customize this operation. You can specify options as either an XML element in the "xdmp:http" namespace, or as a map:map. For details on the supported options, see xdmp:http-getxdmp.httpGet.

apidoc:usage.p: The http functions only operate on URIs that use the http or https schemes; specifying a URI that does not begin with http:// or https:// throws an exception.
If an http function times out, it throws a socket received exception (SVC-SOCRECV).

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp:http-options("http://localhost:8000/", myname mypassword ) => the response from the HTTP server, for example: 302 Found /use-cases/ MarkLogic 0 close

xdmp.httpOptions("http://localhost:8000/", { "authentication" : { "method" : "digest", "username" : "myname", "password" : "mypassword" } }) => the response from the HTTP server, for example: 302 Found /use-cases/ MarkLogic 0 close

apidoc:function.name: http-delete
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Sends an http DELETE request to the http server specified in the URI to delete the specified resource. The server should respond if the request is to be completed, but a response is not guaranteed. Also, even if the server does respond, it does not guarantee that the request has been or will be completed.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The URI of the document to delete.

Options with which to customize this operation. You can specify options as either an XML element in the "xdmp:http" namespace, or as a map:map. For details on the supported options, see xdmp:http-getxdmp.httpGet.

apidoc:usage.p: The http functions only operate on URIs that use the http or https schemes; specifying a URI that does not begin with http:// or https:// throws an exception.
If an http function times out, it throws a socket received exception (SVC-SOCRECV).

Note the xdmp:http-delete function simply sends a DELETE request to the specified web server; what happens with the DELETE request depends on the web server. The request does not delete a document from a MarkLogic Server database. To delete a document from a database, use the
xdmp:document-delete function.

Note the xdmp.httpDelete function simply sends a DELETE request to the specified web server; what happens with the DELETE request depends on the web server. The request does not delete a document from a MarkLogic Server database. To delete a document from a database, use the
xdmp.documentDelete function.

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp:http-delete("http://www.my.com/document.xhtml", <options xmlns="xdmp:http"> <authentication method="basic"> <username>myname</username> <password>mypassword</password> </authentication> </options>) => an optional response from the server

apidoc:function.name: http-post
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Sends an http POST request to the server.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The URI to which the data is to be posted.

Options with which to customize this operation. You can specify options as either an XML element in the "xdmp:http" namespace, or as a map:map. The options names below are XML element localnames. When using a map, replace the hyphens with camel casing. For example, "an-option" becomes "anOption" when used as a map:map key. This function supports the following options, plus the options from the xdmp:http-get xdmp.httpGet function.
<data>
data This option can contain any string. Anything in the data option is sent as a string in the PUT or POST body. When POSTing to a web service, the data may need to be a SOAP XML structure, a JSON structure, or binary content. The optional third argument can be used to specify the body instead.
The other options are the same as the other xdmp:http-*xdmp.http* functions, and the options are documented with the xdmp:http-get xdmp.httpGet $options parameter.
The data for this request. This is an alternative to the data option for the second parameter that allows binary content to be specified for the body of the POST.

apidoc:usage.p: The http functions only operate on URIs that use the http or https schemes; specifying a URI that does not begin with http:// or https:// throws an exception.
If an http function times out, it throws a socket received exception (SVC-SOCRECV).
The function returns a sequence containing the request response. If the reponse is multi-part, then the sequence contains multiple items.

If you expect the request body from this http function to be processed by another application (via a web service, for example), you should specify a content-type header. If no content-type header is specified, the content type defaults to text/plain.

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp:http-post("http://www.my.com/document.xhtml", <options xmlns="xdmp:http"> <authentication method="basic"> <username>myname</username> <password>mypassword</password> </authentication> </options>) => the response from the server as well as the specified document

(: Use xdmp:quote to encode the XML as a string because the <data> options element is a string :) let $payload := xdmp:quote( <SOAP-ENV:Envelope xmlns:SOAP-ENV='http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/' xmlns:xsd='http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema' xmlns:xsi='http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance' xmlns:SOAP-ENC='http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/' xmlns:my='urn:MyConnection'> <SOAP-ENV:Body> <my:LogOn> <my:User>user</my:User> <my:Password>pass</my:Password> <my:Ticket>abc123</my:Ticket> <my:newData>1234</my:newData> </my:LogOn> </SOAP-ENV:Body> </SOAP-ENV:Envelope> ) return xdmp:http-post("http://www.my.com/document.xhtml", <options xmlns="xdmp:http"> <authentication method="basic"> <username>myname</username> <password>mypassword</password> </authentication> <data>{$payload}</data> <headers> <content-type>application/xml</content-type> </headers> </options>) => the response from the server as well as the specified document

xquery version "1.0-ml";
let $payload := '{ "user-name": "joe", "password": "cool" ,"role": [ "rest-reader" , "rest-writer" ] }' return xdmp:http-post("http://localhost:8002/manage/v2/users?format=json", <options xmlns="xdmp:http"> <authentication method="digest"> <username>myname</username> <password>mypassword</password> </authentication> <data>{$payload}</data> </options>) => the response from the server, and in this example, the new user (joe) is created

apidoc:function.name: http-put
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Sends an HTTP PUT request to an HTTP server. The HTTP server should return a response, which will differ depending on the action the HTTP server takes for the PUT.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The URI to which the data is to be put.

Options with which to customize this operation. You can specify options as either an XML element in the "xdmp:http" namespace, or as a map:map. The options names below are XML element localnames. When using a map, replace the hyphens with camel casing. For example, "an-option" becomes "anOption" when used as a map:map key. This function supports the following options, plus the options from the xdmp:http-get xdmp.httpGet function.
data This option can contain any string. Anything in the data option is sent as a string in the PUT body. To put binary data in the request body, use the optional third parameter instead.
The other options are the same as the other xdmp:http-*xdmp.http* functions, and the options are documented with the xdmp:http-get xdmp.httpGet $options parameter.
Data to put in the request body. This is an alternative to the data option for the second parameter that allows binary content to be specified for the body of the PUT.

apidoc:usage.p: The http functions only operate on URIs that use the http or https schemes; specifying a URI that does not begin with http:// or https:// throws an exception.
If an http function times out, it throws a socket received exception (SVC-SOCRECV).

If you expect the request body from this http function to be processed by another application (via a web service, for example), you should specify a content-type header. If no content-type header is specified, the content type defaults to text/plain.

apidoc:example.pre: (: Send a PUT request to insert a document into the database : using the MarkLogic REST Client API /documents endpoint. The : PUT body contains serialized XML that becomes the content of : the new document. The data for the PUT body is passed as : serialized XML in the options parameter. :) xdmp:http-put("http://example.com:8000/v1/documents?uri=my.xml" myname mypassword application/xml application/xml { xdmp:quote(this is my content) } ) (: MarkLogic returns the response from the HTTP server. In this case, : a response similar to the following: : : : 204 : Content Updated : : MarkLogic : 0 : Keep-Alive : timeout=5 : : :)

(: Send a PUT request to insert a document into the database : using the MarkLogic REST Client API /documents endpoint. The : PUT body contains serialized XML that becomes the content of : the new document. The data for the PUT body is passed as : an XML node in the 3rd parameter. :) xdmp:http-put("http://example.com:8000/v1/documents?uri=my.xml" myname mypassword application/xml application/xml , this is xml for the PUT body) (: MarkLogic returns the response from the HTTP server. In this case, : a response similar to the following: : : : 204 : Content Updated : : MarkLogic : 0 : Keep-Alive : timeout=5 : : :)

apidoc:function.name: base64-encode
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Converts plaintext into base64-encoded string.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: Plaintext to be encoded.

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp:base64-encode("slings and arrows of outrageous fortune") => c2xpbmdzIGFuZCBhcnJvd3Mgb2Ygb3V0cmFnZW91cyBmb3J0dW5l
xdmp.base64Encode("slings and arrows of outrageous fortune"); => c2xpbmdzIGFuZCBhcnJvd3Mgb2Ygb3V0cmFnZW91cyBmb3J0dW5l

apidoc:function.name: base64-decode
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Converts base64-encoded string to plaintext.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: Encoded text to be decoded.

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp:base64-decode( "c2xpbmdzIGFuZCBhcnJvd3Mgb2Ygb3V0cmFnZW91cyBmb3J0dW5l") => slings and arrows of outrageous fortune

apidoc:function.name: subbinary
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns a binary node made up of a subset of the given binary node.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A binary node whose subset will be returned
The new binary node starts at the byte position indicated by starting-location. The first byte is at location 1.
The length in bytes of the new binary node.

apidoc:usage.p: Usage is exactly like fn:substring except that it applies to a binary node rather than a string.

apidoc:function.name: external-binary
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns an external binary node.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: Filesystem path to the external binary file.
The new binary node starts at the byte position indicated by starting-location. The first byte is at location 1. The default value is 1.
The length in bytes of the content in the new binary node. Omitting the length has performance implications; see usage notes.

apidoc:usage.p: If no length is provided, the length is calculated from the starting position and the filesystem length of the external file. If the file does not exist when the length is calculated, XDMP-MISSINGFILE is thrown.

If a length is provided, the length is trusted. That is, no attempt is made to confirm the existence or read the length of the external file. Therefore, including the length in the call (if known) results in the best performance during document creation.

apidoc:example.pre:
xdmp:external-binary("/testdata1/logo.gif", 1, 2456)
=> A binary node representing the external file at /testdata1/logo.gif, beginning at offset 1, with a length of 2456 bytes.

xdmp.externalBinary("/testdata1/logo.gif", 1, 2456);
=> A binary node representing the external file at /testdata1/logo.gif, beginning at offset 1, with a length of 2456 bytes.

apidoc:function.name: binary-size
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the size of the data, in bytes, represented by a binary node.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A binary node whose data size will be returned.

apidoc:function.name: binary-is-external
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Test whether or not a binary node represents an external binary.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The binary mode to be tested.

apidoc:usage.p: An external binary node is one created using xdmp:external-binary. For more details, see "Working With Binary Documents" in the Application Developer's Guide.

apidoc:function.name: binary-is-small
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Check whether a binary node is a small binary.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A binary node

apidoc:usage.p:
A small binary is one whose size is below the large size threshold. See
admin:database-set-large-size-threshold. For details, see "Working With Binary Documents" in the Application Developer's Guide.

apidoc:example.pre:
xdmp:binary-is-small(doc("/logo.gif")/binary())
=> true if the binary content is below the large size threshold.

xdmp.binaryIsSmall(cts.doc("/logo.gif").root)
=> true if the binary content is below the large size threshold.

apidoc:function.name: binary-is-large
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Check whether a binary node is a large binary.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The binary node to test.

apidoc:usage.p: A large binary is one whose size is above the large size threshold. See admin:database-set-large-size-threshold. This function returns false for small and external binary nodes. For details, see "Working With Binary Documents" in the Application Developer's Guide.

apidoc:function.name: external-binary-path
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Return the path to the external file associated with an external binary document.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The external binary node for which to retrieve the external file path.

apidoc:usage.p: If the source binary node does not represent an external binary binary document, XDMP-ARG is thrown. That is, the source binary node must have been created by xdmp:external-binary. Use xdmp:binary-is-external to test whether or not a node represents an external binary.

apidoc:function.name: trace
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Signal a trace event. If trace events are activated and the event is enabled, the trace event is logged.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The trace event name.
The trace event data.

apidoc:function.name: set
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Set the value of a variable to the specified expression. The xdmp:set command allows you to introduce changes to the state (side effects) of a query by changing the value of a variable to something other than what it is bound to.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A variable to set.
A value to set the variable.

apidoc:function.apidoc:usage: When a variable is bound to a sequence in a for loop, and when that variable is changed by xdmp:set in the return clause, the change only affects the value for one iteration of the for loop at a time; when the next value is sent to the return clause, it is set to the next value in the sequence specified in the for clause. The value changes only after the xdmp:set call is made.

apidoc:function.name: host
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the ID of the host named in the parameter. Returns the ID of the current host if no parameter is specified.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The name of the host. The default value is the name of the current host.

apidoc:function.name: host-name
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the name of the specified host.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A host ID.

apidoc:function.name: host-group
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the ID of the group that the specified host belongs to.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A host ID.

apidoc:function.name: software-version
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns this host's software version

apidoc:function.name: effective-version
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the effective version of this host

apidoc:function.name: host-mode
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns this host mode

apidoc:function.name: host-mode-description
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Return the description string for this host mode setting

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A host ID.

apidoc:function.name: hosts
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns a sequence of the IDs of all the hosts in the cluster.

apidoc:function.name: bootstrap-hosts
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns a sequence of the IDs of all the bootstrap hosts in the cluster.

apidoc:function.name: cluster
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the ID of the cluster named in the parameter. Returns the ID of the current cluster if no parameter is specified.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The name of the cluster. The default value is the name of the current cluster.

apidoc:function.name: cluster-name
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the name of the cluster with the specified ID. Returns the name of the current cluster if no ID is specified.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The ID of the cluster. The default value is the ID of the current cluster.

apidoc:function.name: foreign-clusters
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the IDs of the foreign clusters.

apidoc:function.name: server
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Return the ID(s) of the App Servers, XDBC Servers, ODBC Servers, or Task Servers with the given name. Returns the ID of the current server if no parameter is specified.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A server name.
A group to search. If not specified, all groups are searched.

apidoc:function.name: servers
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns a sequence of the IDs of all the App Servers (HTTP, XDBC, ODBC, and TaskServer) in the system.

apidoc:function.name: groups
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns a sequence of the IDs of all the groups in the system.

apidoc:function.name: group
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the ID of the group specified in the parameter. Returns the ID of the current group if no parameter is specified.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The name of the group. The default value is the name of the group the current host belongs to.

apidoc:function.name: group-name
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the name of the group with the given ID. Returns the name of the current group if no parameter is specified.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The ID of the group. The default value is the ID of the group to which the current host belongs.

apidoc:function.name: group-hosts
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the IDs of all hosts belonging to the group with the given ID. If no parameter is specified, it uses the group of the current host.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The ID of the group. The default value is the ID of the group to which the current host belongs.

apidoc:function.name: group-servers
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the IDs of all App Servers belonging to the group with the given ID. If no parameter is specified, it uses the group of the current host.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The ID of the group. The default value is the ID of the group to which the current host belongs.

apidoc:function.name: group-port-servers
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the IDs of all port App Servers belonging to the group with the given ID. If no parameter is specified, it uses the group of the current host.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The ID of the group. The default value is the ID of the group to which the current host belongs.

apidoc:function.name: group-task-server
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the ID of the Task Server belonging to the group with the given ID. If no parameter is specified, it uses the group of the current host.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The ID of the group. The default value is the ID of the group to which the current host belongs.

apidoc:function.name: request
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the unique key of the current request.

apidoc:function.name: modules-root
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the current root path for modules.

apidoc:function.name: diacritic-less
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the specified string, converting all of the characters with diacritics to characters without diacritics.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The string to convert.

apidoc:function.name: collation-canonical-uri
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the canonical URI for the given URI, if it represents a valid collation. A canonical URI is the unique string MarkLogic Server uses to identify a given collation. The canonical URI string places any attributes that occur in the URI in a predefined order, and it removes any attributes that are redundant due to locale defaults.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A collation URI.

apidoc:function.apidoc:usage: If the specified collation URI is not a valid URI, an exception is thrown.

apidoc:function.name: map
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Creates a map.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A serialized map element.

apidoc:example.pre:
xquery version "1.0-ml";
let $map := <map:map xmlns:map="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/map"> <map:entry key="2"> <map:value xsi:type="xs:string" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" >world</map:value> </map:entry> <map:entry key="1"> <map:value xsi:type="xs:string" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" >hello</map:value> </map:entry> </map:map> return map:get(map:map($map), "2") => world

apidoc:function.name: new
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Constructs a new map by combining the keys from the maps given as an argument. If a given key exists in more than one argument map, the value from the last such map is used.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The argument maps.

apidoc:example.pre:
<result>{ map:new(( map:entry("a","aardvark"), map:entry("b","badger") )) }</result>
=> <result> <map:map xmlns:map="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/map" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <map:entry key="b"> <map:value xsi:type="xs:string">badger</map:value> </map:entry> <map:entry key="a"> <map:value xsi:type="xs:string">aardvark</map:value> </map:entry> </map:map> </result>

apidoc:function.name: entry
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Constructs a new map with a single entry consisting of the key and value specified as arguments. This is particularly helpful when used as part of an argument to map:new().

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The map key.
The map value.

apidoc:function.name: put
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Put a value into a map at the given key.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A map.
A key. If the key is not unique, it will overwrite the existing key.
A value. If the value is the empty sequence, it will remove the key from the map.

apidoc:example.pre:
let $map := map:map() let $put := map:put($map, "some-key", <info>45683</info>) return <result>{$map}</result>
=> <result> <map:map xmlns:map="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/map" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <map:entry key="some-key"> <map:value> <info>45683</info> </map:value> </map:entry> </map:map> </result>

apidoc:function.name: with
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Updates a map, inserting a value into it at the given key. The map is returned as the result.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A map.
A key. If the key is not unique, it will overwrite the existing key.
A value. If the value is the empty sequence, it will remove the key from the map.

apidoc:function.name: get
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Get a value from a map.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A map.
A key.

apidoc:function.name: contains
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns true if the key exists in the map.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A map.
A key.

apidoc:function.name: keys
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Get the keys used in the map.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A map.

apidoc:function.name: clear
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Clear a map.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A map.

apidoc:function.name: count
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the number of keys used in the map.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A map.

apidoc:example.pre: (: assume $table is bound to a map with 15 keys :) map:count($table) => 15

let $map := map:map() let $_map := map:put($map, "a", 1) let $_map := map:put($map, "a", 2) let $_map := map:put($map, "b", 1) let $_map := map:put($map, "b", 2) return ($map, map:count($map)) => map:map( <map:map xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:map="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/map"> <map:entry key="b"> <map:value xsi:type="xs:integer">2</map:value> </map:entry> <map:entry key="a"> <map:value xsi:type="xs:integer">2</map:value> </map:entry> </map:map>) 2

apidoc:function.name: delete
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Delete a value from a map.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A map.
A key.

apidoc:function.name: set-javascript-by-ref
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: If true is specified, sets a map:map to be passed to JavaScript by reference. By default, a map:map is passed to JavaScript by value.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A map.
True or false.

apidoc:function.name: binding
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary:
Creates a sem:binding object, which is a sub-type of json:object (and map:map).
This function is a built-in.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A serialized sem:binding object.

apidoc:function.name: object
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Creates a JSON object, which is a kind of map with a fixed and ordered set of keys.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A serialized JSON object.

apidoc:example.pre:
xquery version "1.0-ml";
let $obj := <json:object xmlns:json="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/json"> <json:entry> <json:key>2</json:key> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> world</json:value> </json:entry> <json:entry> <json:key>1</json:key> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> hello</json:value> </json:entry> </json:object> return map:keys(json:object($obj)) => 2 1

apidoc:function.name: object-define
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Creates a JSON object.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The sequence of keys in this object.

apidoc:function.name: array
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Creates a (JSON) array, which is like a sequence of values, but allows for nesting.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A serialized array element.

apidoc:example.pre:
xquery version "1.0-ml";
json:array( <json:array xmlns:json="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/json" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">hello</json:value> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">world</json:value> <json:array> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">one</json:value> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">two</json:value> </json:array> </json:array> ) => ["hello", "world", ["one", "two"]]

apidoc:function.name: to-array
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Constructs json:array from a sequence of items.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A sequence of items.

The size of the array to construct. If the size is less than the length of the item sequence, only as "limit" items are put into the array. If the size is more than the length of the sequence, the array is filled with null values up to the limit.
The value to use to pad out the array, if necessary. By default the empty sequence is used.

apidoc:function.apidoc:usage: Use this function to construct an in-memory object that represents a JSON array, suitable for use with xdmp:to-json. This function does not produce an array node. To construct an array node, use the array-node constructor.

apidoc:example.pre:
xquery version "1.0-ml";
json:to-array(1 to 2) => json:array( <json:array xmlns:json="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/json" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <json:value xsi:type="xs:integer">1</json:value> <json:value xsi:type="xs:integer">2</json:value> </json:array> )

apidoc:function.name: array-values
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the array values as an XQuery sequence.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An array.
Include values from subarrays in the sequence. The default is false, meaning that subarrays are returned as array values.

apidoc:example.pre:
xquery version "1.0-ml";
let $array := json:array( <json:array xmlns:json="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/json" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">hello</json:value> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">world</json:value> <json:array> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">one</json:value> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">two</json:value> </json:array> </json:array> ) return json:array-values($array) => ("hello", "world", ["one", "two"])

xquery version "1.0-ml";
let $array := json:array( <json:array xmlns:json="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/json" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">hello</json:value> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">world</json:value> <json:array> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">one</json:value> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">two</json:value> </json:array> </json:array> ) return json:array-values($array, fn:true()) => ("hello", "world", "one", "two")

apidoc:function.name: arrayValues
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the array values as a Sequence.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An array.
Include values from subarrays in the sequence. The default is false, meaning that subarrays are returned as array values.

apidoc:example.pre: var a = ["hello","world",["one","two"]]; xdmp.arrayValues(a,true); => A Sequence with the following values: hello world one two

apidoc:function.name: array-size
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the size of the array.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An array.

apidoc:function.name: set-item-at
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Sets a value in an array at a specified position.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An array.
The position to update. Invalid positions throw XDMP-ARRAYINDEXOUTOFBOUNDS
A value. Empty sequences are allowed.

apidoc:example.pre:
let $array := json:to-array( ("a","b","c"), 5 ) let $put := json:set-item-at($array, 5 , <info>45683</info>) return <result>{$array}</result>
=> <result> <json:array xmlns:json="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/json"> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">a</json:value> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">b</json:value> <json:value xsi:type="xs:string">c</json:value> <json:value xsi:nil="true"/> <json:value><info>45683</info></json:value> </json:array> </result>

apidoc:function.name: array-resize
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Resize the array to the new size. If the new size is greater than the old size, the new entries will be null. If the new size if smaller than the old size, the extra entries will be removed.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An array.
New size.
The value to use to pad out the array, if necessary. By default the empty sequence is used.

apidoc:function.name: array-push
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Push a value to the end of the array, increasing the size of the array by one.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An array.
New entries.

apidoc:function.name: array-with
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Push a value to the end of the array, increasing the size of the array by one. Returns the array as the result.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An array.
New entries.

apidoc:function.name: array-pop
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Pop a value from the end of the array.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An array.

apidoc:function.name: subarray
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Extract a subarray from an array, producing a new array. The second and third arguments to this function operate similarly to those of fn:subsequence for XQuery sequences.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An array.
The starting position of the start of the subarray.
The length of the subarray.

apidoc:function.name: array-set-javascript-by-ref
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: If true is specified, sets a json:array to be passed to JavaScript by reference. By default, a map:map is passed to JavaScript by value.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A json array.
True or false.

apidoc:function.name: null
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the JSON null value, which is an empty sequence to XQuery, but not a Sequence when passed to JavaScript.

apidoc:function.name: sleep
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Delays for a specific amount of time.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The amount of time to sleep, in milliseconds.

apidoc:function.name: with-namespaces
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Evaluates the expression in the context of a specific set of namespace bindings.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A set of namespace prefix bindings, expressed as either a sequence of alternating (prefix,uri) pairs, or a map:map where the keys are prefixes and the values are namespace URIs. If the prefix is the empty string, the following URI becomes the default namespace of the resulting item(s).
An expression to evaluate in the context of the given namespace bindings.

apidoc:example.pre:
(: Using a sequence of prefix-URI pairs to define the bindings :) let $version := "1.2" return xdmp:with-namespaces(("p", fn:concat("http://marklogic.com/p/",$version)), <p:bar/> )
(: Returns: <p:bar xmlns:p="http://marklogic.com/p/1.2"/> :)

(: Using a map:map to define the bindings :) let $version := "1.2" return xdmp:with-namespaces( map:map() => map:with("p", fn:concat("http://marklogic.com/p/",$version)), <p:bar/> )
(: Returns: <p:bar xmlns:p="http://marklogic.com/p/1.2"/> :)

apidoc:function.name: element-content-type
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the schema-defined content-type of an element ("empty", "simple", "element-only", or "mixed").

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An element node.

apidoc:function.name: pretty-print
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns a well-formatted XQuery module.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: An XQuery module to be reformatted.

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp:pretty-print("for $x in 1 to 10 return $x") => "for $x in 1 to 10 return $x"

apidoc:function.name: key-from-QName
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Construct a context-independent string from a QName. This string is of the form "{namespaceURI}localname" and is suitable for use as a map key.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The QName to compute a key for.

apidoc:example.pre:
(: Using a QName with an in-scope namespace prefix :) xquery version "1.0-ml"; xdmp:key-from-QName(xs:QName("xs:string"))
(: Returns output of the following form: {http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema}string
The generated key includes the XMLSchema namespace URI because the "xs" namespace binding is implicitly defined in MarkLogic. :)

(: Using a QName with an arbitrary namespace :) xquery version "1.0-ml"; xdmp:key-from-QName(fn:QName("/my/namespace","thing"))
(: Returns output of the following form: {/my/namespace}thing :)

apidoc:function.name: QName-from-key
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Construct a QName from a string of the form "{namespaceURI}localname". This function is useful for constructing Clark notation parameters for the xdmp:xslt-eval and xdmp:xslt-invoke functions.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The string from which to construct a QName.

apidoc:example.pre:
(: Using a key based on an arbitrary namespace :) xquery version "1.0-ml"; xdmp:QName-from-key("{/my/namespace}thing")
(: Returns output of the following form: thing :)

apidoc:summary.p: Create a multipart encoding of the specified node. The returned binary node can be passed to xdmp:http-post. The manifest is modeled after the manifest that is passed to zip:create, with the headers element being the same as is described for xdmp:http-get allowing users to add arbitrary headers to each part. If a content-type header is not specified for a part, it will be determined if possible from the content.
There should be one part element for each node in the content sequence.
Each part also has an optional options node to control how xml or text will be serialized. The two options are the same as for xdmp:save.
The manifest can also be defined as a JSON array.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The string that is to be used as a separator.
The manifest.
The nodes that are to be encoded.
The manifest.
The nodes that are to be encoded.

apidoc:example.pre:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; let $html := document{

Some stuff in an .html document

} let $xml := document{ Some other stuff in a .xml document } let $json := xdmp:to-json(("a",fn:false())) let $boundary-string := "gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p" return xdmp:multipart-encode( $boundary-string, application/xml gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p text/html application/json , ($xml,$html,$json) ) => --gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p Content-Type: application/xml boundary: gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p Content-Length: 94 Some other stuff in a .xml document --gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p Content-Type: text/html Content-Length: 90

Some stuff in an .html document

--gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p Content-Type: application/json Content-Length: 12 ["a", false] --gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p--

var html = fn.head(xdmp.unquote( '

Some stuff in an .html document

')); var xml = fn.head(xdmp.unquote(' \n\ Some other stuff in a .xml document \n\ ')); var json = xdmp.toJSON(["a",false]); var boundaryString = "gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p"; var manifest = fn.head(xdmp.unquote( '' + '' + 'application/xml' + 'gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p' + '' + '' + 'text/html ' + 'application/json' + '')).root; xdmp.multipartEncode( boundaryString, manifest, [xml,html,json] ); => --gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p Content-Type: application/xml boundary: gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p Content-Length: 94 Some other stuff in a .xml document --gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p Content-Type: text/html Content-Length: 90

Some stuff in an .html document

--gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p Content-Type: application/json Content-Length: 12 ["a", false] --gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p--

apidoc:summary.p: Extract the parts from a multipart encoding. The first item in the sequence is a manifest, and the remaining items are the decoded parts.

An attempt will be made to determine the type of content based on headers such as the part's content-type. If possible, an element will be returned, falling back to an xs:string, and finally binary().

The options control how the parts are unpacked, and are similar to xdmp:zip-get - default-namespace, repair, format, default-language, and encoding. The options apply to all parts, so specifying a format of binary will cause all parts to be returned as binary, and specifying text will cause all parts to be returned as xs:string if possible, falling back to binary() if necessary. This is useful if different parts need different options, in which case the resulting strings can each be passed to xdmp:unquote() with appropriate options.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The string that is to be used as a separator.
The data (as a binary node) to be decoded.
Decode options.

apidoc:example.pre:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; let $html := document{

Some stuff in an .html document

} let $xml := document{ Some other stuff in a .xml document } let $json := xdmp:to-json(("a",fn:false())) let $boundary-string := "gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p" let $mpe := xdmp:multipart-encode( $boundary-string, application/xml gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p text/html application/json , ($xml,$html,$json) ) return xdmp:multipart-decode($boundary-string, $mpe) => application/xml gc0p4Jq0M2Yt08jU534c0p 94 text/html 90 application/json 12 Some other stuff in a .xml document

Some stuff in an .html document

["a", false]

apidoc:function.name: encoding-language-detect
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Analyzes binary, text, or XML data and suggests possible pairs of encoding and language, with a confidence score for each pair. Scores of 10 and above are high confidence recommendations. The results are given in order of decreasing score. Accuracy may be poor for short documents.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: Node to be analyzed for possible encodings and languages. If the node is an XML element or document node, the function takes the string value of the specified node (equivalent of fn:string($node)) to detect the encoding and language.

apidoc:usage.p: If the input is very small (for example, less than two words), then this built-in returns the empty sequence.
For best results, the input should be at least several hundred bytes.

apidoc:function.name: binary-decode
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Converts an encoded byte sequence, passed in as a binary node, from the specified encoding to a unicode string.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A binary node containing the encoded stream.

Specifies the encoding to use when decoding the document. Supported values include UTF-8 and ISO-8859-1. The string specifed for the encoding option will be matched to a registered encoding name using the Unicode Charset Alias Matching rules (http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr22/#Charset_Alias_Matching).

apidoc:example.pre: xdmp:binary-decode( fn:doc("binary_doc_encoded_as_ShiftJIS.dat")/node(), "UTF-8") => contents of document after decoding, in unicode characters
xdmp.binaryDecode( cts.doc("binary_doc_encoded_as_ShiftJIS.dat").root, "UTF-8"); => contents of document after decoding, in unicode characters

apidoc:function.name: host-forests
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns a sequence of forest IDs in the specified host.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: A host ID.

apidoc:function.name: validate
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns an element containing a summary of validation errors in a node.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The node to validate.
The validation mode, either "strict", "lax", or "type".
The name of the type to validate against, if the mode is "type". An error is raised if a typeName is given with a different validation mode, or if no type is given if the mode is "type".

apidoc:example.pre:
declare namespace t="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/thesaurus"; xdmp:validate( document { <t:thesaurus> <t:entry> <t:term>one</t:term> <t:notes>unexpected stuff</t:notes> <t:part-of-speech>expl</t:part-of-speech> <t:synonym> <t:term>unique</t:term> </t:synonym> </t:entry> </t:thesaurus> } ) =>

apidoc:function.name: timestamp-to-wallclock
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Converts a 64 bit timestamp value to an xs:dateTime.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The timestamp.

apidoc:function.name: wallclock-to-timestamp
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Converts an xs:dateTime to a 64 bit timestamp value.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The xs:datetime value.

apidoc:function.name: configuration-timestamp
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns timestamp of last configuration changed

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The name of configuration file. The default value is empty string.

apidoc:function.name: eager
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the value of its argument, evaluated eagerly.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The value to return

apidoc:function.name: lazy
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the value of its argument, evaluated lazily.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The value to return

apidoc:function.name: caller-dialect
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the dialect (e.g., "javascript", "1.0-ml", etc) of the caller or the empty sequence if no dialect information is available. Note that the return is not the language the function that calls this built-in is written in; it is the dialect the function is called from. For example, if a JavaScript program calls function "foo", which uses xdmp:caller-dialect, then the return from xdmp:caller-dialect will be javascript even if "foo" is implemented in XQuery.

apidoc:function.name: ldap-search
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns ldap search result. The function returns a Sequence containing objects, where each object is an ldap attribute with its value.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The query is a string representation of the filter to apply in the search. The string should conform to the format specified in RFC 4515 as extended by RFC 4526. For example, "(cn=Jane Doe)".

Options with which to customize this operation. You can specify options as either an XML element in the "xdmp:ldap" namespace, or as a map:map. The options names below are XML element localnames. When using a map, replace the hyphens with camel casing. For example, "an-option" becomes "anOption" when used as a map:mapkey. This function supports the following options:
"username" ldap username. "password" ldap password. "server-uri" "serverUri" ldap server uri. "search-base" "searchBase" search-base is the DN of the entry at which to start the search. "use-appserver-config" "useAppserverConfig" Use appserver config as default. Specify true or false. The default is false. "bind-method" "bindMethod" ldap bind method. Specify simple, MD5 or external. "credential-id" "credentialId" The credential to be used to sign the generated certificate. "start-tls" "startTls" start tls (Transport Layer Security) extended operation. Specify true or false. The default is false. "certificate" "certificate" client certificate. "private-key" "privateKey" private key for the client certificate.

apidoc:example.pre:
xdmp:ldap-search( "(cn=Jane Doe)", <options xmlns="xdmp:ldap"> <username>admin</username> <password>admin</password> <server-uri>ldap://dc1.mltest1.local:389</server-uri> <search-base>CN=Users,DC=MLTEST1,DC=LOCAL</search-base> </options>)
=> <ldap-object xmlns="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/ldap/object"> <ldap-attribute id="DN">CN=Jane Doe,CN=Users,DC=MLTEST1,DC=LOCAL</ldap-attribute> <ldap-attribute id="objectClass">top</ldap-attribute> apidoc:function.name: ldap-lookup
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns an ldap entry.

apidoc:params.apidoc:param: The DN of the entry to be returned.

Options with which to customize this operation. You can specify options as either an XML element in the "xdmp:ldap" namespace, or as a map:map. The options names below are XML element localnames. When using a map, replace the hyphens with camel casing. For example, "an-option" becomes "anOption" when used as a map:mapkey. This function supports the following options:
username ldap username. password ldap password. server-uri serverUri ldap server uri. use-appserver-config useAppserverConfig Use appserver config as default. Specify true or false. The default is false. bind-method bindMethod ldap bind method. Specify simple, MD5 or external. credential-id credentialId The credential to be used to sign the generated certificate. "start-tls" "startTls" start tls (Transport Layer Security) extended operation. Specify true or false. The default is false. "certificate" "certificate" client certificate. "private-key" "privateKey" private key for the client certificate.

apidoc:function.name: aws-region
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the current Amazon Web Services region. If MarkLogic is not running on Amazon web Services, returns an empty sequence.
Returns the current Amazon Web Services region. If MarkLogic is not running on Amazon web Services, returns null.

apidoc:function.name: aws-services-domain
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the current Amazon Web Services services domain. If MarkLogic is not running on Amazon Web Services, returns an empty sequence.
Returns the current Amazon Web Services services domain. If MarkLogic is not running on Amazon Web Services, returns null.

apidoc:function.name: aws-services-partition
apidoc:function.apidoc:summary: Returns the current Amazon Web Services services partition. If MarkLogic is not running on Amazon Web Services, returns an empty sequence.
Returns the current Amazon Web Services services partition. If MarkLogic is not running on Amazon Web Services, returns null.
